"Killers of the Flower Moon" is a gripping historical drama showcasing stellar performances and an evocative narrative. One of the standout elements is Leonardo DiCaprio's transformation, achieved through prosthetics that alter his appearance dramatically, giving him a permanent frown reminiscent of Orson Welles. DiCaprio's acting reaches its pinnacle in a heart-wrenching scene where he processes the death of his daughter, delivering a performance that feels raw and genuine. Lily Gladstone, however, emerges as the film's most captivating presence. Her expressive eyes communicate a profound depth, keeping the audience guessing whether her character is aware of the sinister plans around her. Gladstone's portrayal adds an air of mystery and emotional weight to the story. Robert De Niro, as expected, is masterful, bringing a duality to his role as a public figure and a Mafia boss, blending menace with charisma. Supporting performances from Jesse Plemons and Brendan Fraser are equally compelling, with Fraser's physicality adding an intimidating dynamic to the courtroom scenes. Martin Scorsese's direction is exemplary, blending his signature style with historical authenticity. The film seamlessly integrates archival photographs and dynamic sequences, such as a memorable scene mixing rock and Native American music during a discovery of oil. The period setting is brought to life through meticulous attention to detail, from vintage cars to cultural nuances, creating a vivid depiction of 1920s America. The narrative also highlights racial tensions and the early days of the FBI, offering a sobering reflection on the era's complexities. Despite its strengths, the film isn't without flaws. Some editing choices, such as continuity errors and a broken 180-degree rule in a conversation, stand out as distractions. DiCaprio's accent, while period-appropriate, feels slightly forced and occasionally pulls focus from the story. At three hours long, the pacing falters at times, particularly in the early sections, which may lose some viewers' engagement. Emotionally, the death of Gladstone's character’s mother fails to resonate as strongly as intended, which detracts from the film's otherwise powerful emotional core. Additionally, DiCaprio's morally corrupt character may surprise viewers expecting a more traditional hero, ultimately shifting the narrative's emotional center to Gladstone. In conclusion, "Killers of the Flower Moon" is an ambitious film that succeeds in delivering a compelling story with remarkable performances and meticulous craftsmanship. While not without minor shortcomings, its powerful themes, exceptional acting, and Scorsese's visionary direction make it a memorable cinematic experience.

Another great film by the master craftsman, Martin Scorsese. It is unbelievable that he is still at the top of his game at 80 years old. The acting is great, especially in the case of Lily Gladstone. Robert De Niro, who is also 80 years old, gave one of his career best performances. Leonardo Dicaprio gave an exceptional performance as well. The cinematography is a thing of beauty! The signature Scorsese camera work is something to behold. The way the camera moves seamlessly through the house at a high rate of speed around the 44 minute mark is vintage Martin Scorsese. Him pulling off that shot with those mirrors on the wall is an impressive feat to say the least. I love Martin's cameo appearance at the end of the film. That entire sequence was a rather creative way to update the audience on the years that followed. Rather than simply using inserts, Mr. Scorsese chose to present the story in the style of a stage play, which was really effective, in my opinion. I love the final shot, which shows the resilience of the Osage people with the use of an elevating bird's eye view shot, showing the modern day tribe, dancing and celebrating, leaving the audience with something in the way of a happy ending. Killers of the Flower Moon is a great, yet dark motion picture that is even better upon a second viewing. I most definitely recommend this film. 95/100

I'm honestly not sure if my problem with this movie stems from me first reading the book or that because it is a Martin Scorsese movie that means everyone thinks it's instantly good. Firstly, I'm not sure who decided that this story needed to be told from Ernest's perspective, but that person should be ashamed of their decision. The book was more of a murder mystery non-fiction, and if anything it was mostly from the FBI agent's perspective because it was based off his notes in the actual case. Ernest is a reprehensible, spineless tool, and although the movie demonstrates that at times, it very weirdly tries to get us to empathize with him as well. It makes it seem like he was just a man put in this position and things grew out of his control, but he knew from the beginning what the plan was and went along with it anyway. It also just seems like bad storytelling to me to lay out the perpetrators and plan of this murder plot right from the start, and have the audience watch the police/FBI fumble around while we know exactly what happened. This story was poorly written/adapted, and it doesn't matter that Martin Scorsese was the director or that the acting was amazing because none of that is able to fix a bad screenplay.

Based on a true story, Scorsese’s latest outing tells the tale of a 1920’s Oklahoma family that tries to “inherit” Osage Indian land by marrying the landowners and then murdering them. This was news to me, but yeah, that really happened. Apparently, something like 60 Osage Indians were murdered over the course of a decade in these schemes, leading the U.S. Government to change laws regarding inheritance of Native American land. Unfortunately, the film is just too damn long. Clocking in at three and a half hours, it takes an interesting premise and just drags it out to the point of being boring. This seems to be an unexpected consequence of the streaming era. In the old days, studios were a lot more demanding with filmmakers when it came to runtime. This ensured they could get as many daily showings in a cinema as possible. With more viewers waiting to stream films, runtime seems to be less important to studios, allowing filmmakers to indulge to the detriment of their own films. Leaving an hour of this one on the cutting room floor would have benefited this film immensely.

Killers of the Flower Moon is a crime western that is adapted from the book of the same name, telling the story of The Osage Murders and how the events occurred. The movie stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Lily Gladstone in the leads as Ernest and Mollie Burkhart. The movie also stars Robert De Niro, Brendan Fraser and is directed by the infamous Martin Scorsese. Just like many people going into this movie, I didn't know anything about this true story and these events that took place but the trailer intrigued me enough and after a few tries of watching this 3 and a half hour movie, I can happily say that this movie is what cinema is all about. The performances in this movie are no joke and are some of the best acting from an ensemble in a long time. The chemistry between DiCaprio and Gladstone felt so organic and natural, and when the intense drama took place, they both knew how to perfectly deliver their performances. The atmosphere and cinematography in this movie was beautiful, and the best scenes that showed this was probably the opening, or this one scene with an explosion. But most importantly, the story is incredible. I mean, the amount of detail that was put into this story when showing the different points of views and making sure to tell every aspect of the story with such dedication and thoughtfulness is what makes this movie such a masterpiece. The way Scorsese executes certain scenes with this slow pacing that makes up for it with world-building, and telling the story in a way where it's easy to understand and dissect, while also making it entertaining, suspenseful. emotional, and satisfying with the conclusion to this heartbreaking story, it's really incredible and inspiring to see such a true story be brought to the big screen in such a fantastic way. Overall, Killers of the Flower Moon tells a true and real story in an entertaining and suspenseful way, filled with intense drama, incredible performances, this a movie that will be legendary for sure. A-

Killers of the Flower Moon This epic western crime saga recounts the tale of the Osage people in 1920, whose newfound wealth from oil discovery on their land brought both prosperity and a wave of violence and death. "Killers of the Flower Moon" presents a grim examination of how individuals, driven by greed and cowardice, can commit heinous acts. Ernest Burkhart witnesses his uncle's ruthless killings of the Osage people for their wealth and becomes complicit in these atrocities. As the violence seeps into his own home, he remains indifferent, even contemplating ending his wife's life despite his love for her. Despite its lengthy runtime of three and a half hours, the film maintains tight pacing throughout. While it delves deep into the lives of the Osage people, it also explores the broader circumstances surrounding them, offering a comprehensive view of the events that shaped their lives. Leonardo DiCaprio delivers a fully committed portrayal of his character; Ernest embodies both heartlessness and cowardice with chilling authenticity. Robert De Niro, true to form, delivers a stellar performance. Lily Gladstone's portrayal of Mollie stands out as one of the 'daintiest' performances I've witnessed. Despite her character, Mollie, not delivering monologues or extravagant expressions, her gentle demeanor exudes life and commands attention effortlessly. She serves as a brilliant representation of the positive values inherent in her tribe. Martin Scorsese's direction is immersive, and atmospheric, and demands patience from the audience. With meticulous detail, he resurrects a forgotten incident, shedding light on it with painstaking care. While "Killers of the Flower Moon" may pose a challenge due to its lengthy runtime, for those willing to weather the storm, it offers a blend of education and entertainment. 8/10

Recognizing one's limits is one of the greatest demonstrations of humility a person can give. Evidently this is a lesson that Martin Scorsese struggles to learn despite his venerable age, because his latest and interminable effort fully demonstrates what happens when a director embarks on the making of a movie without knowing how to manage its running time. Killers of the flower moon takes what would basically be a plot full of events, mysteries and food for thought and barely manages to give the latter away, staging various events stacked together in a manner totally devoid of pathos and sense of progression of the narrative. Many facts and things happen but somehow the more the minutes pass the more it seems that nothing has happened. The movie is simply correct, to the extent that: the acting, the direction, the photography and the staging are correct. However, there is not an acting performance, a scene, a line of dialogue or a shot that is memorable and a movie directed by someone of Scorsese's caliber is unthinkable that it is "simply correct". Every aspect of the movie is subdued and if this were to be a consequence of his directorial maturation, perhaps Scorsese should have taken refuge in directing a more intimate movie with a less gargantuan duration since he proves to be totally incapable of knowing how to manage it while keeping the audience's attention high from start to finish. Yet in the same year in which this movie was released we had in Oppenheimer a clear example of how the narration of events so distant in time from us can keep us in suspense for 3 hours. The difference between Killers of the flower moon and Oppenheimer, however, lies in the fact that Nolan did not have the same claim as Scorsese to want to teach new generations of spectators what the "right" way of making cinema is, without realizing that times are changed and that the way of making movies has changed. Scorsese's career has suffered no more or less the same decline as those comicbook movies that he did so much to denigrate: it began by entertaining crowds of spectators with countless memorable moments and is concluding with a series of products whose only memorability is linked to their anachronism. Because this too, dear Martin, is cinema and you are part of it.

"Killers of the Flower Moon" unfolds an important chapter of history with captivating storytelling. Clocking in at 3 and a half hours, the film's epic scope might test your patience, but it's a narrative that deservedly demands attention. The Osage wealth from oil becomes a sinister backdrop, drawing in a conspiracy of corruption among guardians, judges, lawyers, doctors, and businessmen. While the runtime may feel excessive for a movie, the intricate worldbuilding and classic Scorsese touch make it a visual treat. Lily Gladstone's Oscar-worthy performance as a standout Osage character adds a layer of brilliance, stealing scenes effortlessly. Despite the slow pacing, the evolution into a full-blown mafia drama feels quintessentially Scorsese. De Niro and DiCaprio deliver solid performances, though Gladstone shines brightest. The soundtrack, deserving of its Oscar nomination, complements the immersive experience. The film's second act, albeit a bit sluggish, weaves a captivating narrative. A surprise cameo in the ending adds an extra layer of satisfaction, enhancing the overall impact. While some might argue for a shorter runtime, the engrossing storytelling keeps your eyes glued to the screen. A few casting tweaks could have enhanced the experience, but the film stands tall as a cinematic achievement. Oscars are beckoning, especially for Lily Gladstone, whose exceptional portrayal deserves the spotlight.

It's that time of year again, when we reflect back on the best of last year's movies. Like clockwork, names that are sure to be part of that list are Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro and Leonardo Dicaprio. Oh and hey, wouldn't you know it, Killers of the Flower Moon has all three. So, naturally critics immediately start throwing around words like "masterpiece" or "perfection, " but does the movie live up to the hype? In a word, no. For starters, this movie is long, I mean REALLY long. While I wouldn't have an issue with the length, if well-paced, this movie was painfully slow. What's worse is I can tell which moments needed to be shaved off. For instance, when I watch a movie, I ask myself, "why did the director want me to see this shot?" Sometimes this can be obvious. When they linger on a specific character or object it could be meant as a piece of foreshadowing, predicting events to come. In this case, however, there were so many unnecessary scenes to the plot, that ultimately slowed the pacing to a crawl. Next, is frankly one of my biggest historical movie faux pas. Watch any older video of the time and you'll find the streets, bars or restaurants vacant, 50-100 people tops, even during the busiest of times. Yet, for some reason, certain directors insist on packing scenes full of people, or activities, to visually stimulate the audience. They'll call it authenticity but I call it "visual noise" and disingenuous. Lastly, some directors prefer a bare scripts to allow their actors the freedom to ad-lib. This is designed to create a natural, authentic (there's that word again) interactions between actors. Unfortunately, without the proper guidance this can lead to uncomfortable and awkward performances. In this case, I feel the better performances were from some the supporting cast rather than the principles.

However... from a screenwriting perspective, I think there's some problems. I haven't read the book yet (I have it in my possession to do so), but I'm betting it's going to be a different perspective than what you see here. I certainly don't think it was an intention of Roth and Scorsese to make the people who were the SUBJECT of the atrocities peripheral to their own story, but unfortunately that's what you kind of get here, despite the director making some valiant attempts to circumvent that. Look, we get it: if your film stars Leo, then the focus is going to be on him, whether it should be or not, but that's the main quibble I have with the film. Small quibble is the length. Yes, yes, "saving cinema" and all that, thanks Marty, but "Goodfellas" is 2 1/2 hours and is, in my opinion, better than this movie. I'm still recommending it, but as I said, I get a feeling that when I'm finished with the book, I'm definitely going to be in the camp that feels the book is much better than the movie. Which is usually the case, I know, but I'm just curious to see what another director with, shall we say, a different perspective, might have brought to the film. With no disrespect to Mr. S, because I remain a big fan. This is just one of his "very good" efforts and not one of his masterpieces, in my opinion.

Putting aside how relentlessly grim the story is, there's an inevitably to the unfolding of events that saps the film of suspense and narrative tension. At three hours, it's a marathon of murder that hardly feels worth the time, except as an overdue admission of guilt.

Seemed like it could have been shorter. Story was filled with repetition, and dragged. This isn't even a top ten 10 Scorsese movie. It felt like a premium TV show not a movie.

First, the good: Lily Gladstone. She deserves any accolades she will get for this film. Now the rest... What could have/should have been a compelling tale of greed and murder became an overly long exercise in directorial ego. This movie is what happens when no one wants to tell a legendary director that they should let an editor take a crack at the film before releasing the director's cut. An interesting story could have been about the Osage and the agents who tracked down the killers. Instead we get a overly long, muddled focus on the criminals. A focus on King and Ernest might have been okay if (1) we had gotten more of a backstory about the criminals (how did King come to be King?, was Ernest always as dumb as he was during the period covered by the film?) or (2) more exploration of the killings and how people in the community reacted to them (more detail on the impact in the community, who did they suspect was responsible?). It's amazing that in 3.5 hours, so many potentially interesting parts of the story were not told. Instead we get vignettes and glimpses which take the place of exposition. Perhaps tell us more about the KKK than a few seconds of them marching in a parade? How about a bit more detail on the relationship of the Osage killing to the Tulsa massacre? A lot of the press has lauded Scorsese for using Native American actors and Osage dialog. This is commendable, but at this point shouldn't that be taken for granted? Is it really so remarkable that a big budget file would do the right thing? And finally, what's with the radio play at the end? So many interesting pieces of the story are jammed into a jarring conclusion that seemed as though even the director knew this had gone on too long but he needed to tie up loose ends. Many films will end with a list the crimes and sentences in a series of scrolls but Scorsese decides to use a radio play as the delivery mechanism. An interesting look into Foley artists and radio play production to be sure, but is that what was important about the wrapup? The significance of the aftermath of the killings took a back seat to the vanity project of showing how radio plays were created. I had hope for this movie despite it's length. Given the critical acclaim, I figured Scorsese had made an important contribution to our understanding of this suppressed period of our history. I was wrong.

Hang up your boots old man while you still have some dignity.

Na década de 20, no século passado, a nação indígena Osage encontra petróleo nas terras da sua reserva, tornando-os milionários. Porém, uma série de mortes e assassinatos começam a acontecer entre eles. Isto é o pano de fundo para a história de Ernest e Molly Burkhart. Ele, um soldado retornando da Primeira Guerra, buscando fortuna. Ela, uma osage rica com o dinheiro do petróleo. Vendo esse filme, logo uma coisa aflora: para certas pessoas, é inconcebível que pessoas não brancas possam ter dinheiro. Fico pensando que os osages talvez achassem que eles seriam aceitos na sociedade dos brancos com o dinheiro do petróleo, mas isso apenas despertou o pior em muitos brancos. O dinheiro dos osages causou uma inversão: os empregados agora eram os brancos. O quanto isso deve ter pirado os preconceituosos! É nesse caldeirão que Ernest chega para ganhar dinheiro, trabalhando para seu tio. E o primeiro diálogo entre Ernest e o seu tio já demonstra todo o mau-caratismo de William Hale. Complementando, temos Molly Brown. Enquanto Ernest é falador, Hale, uma serpente sempre armando e pronta para dar o bote, Molly observa a tudo. Ela percebe as intenções de Ernest quando ele começa a cortejá-la. Ela tenta ser um apoio para a sua família, começando a ser destroçada, com os casamentos com homens brancos. E Molly tem a serenidade e a austeridade que os seus algozes brancos não têm. E que trio espetacular! Di Caprio, De Niro e Lily Gladstone fornecem interpretações magistrais, que merecem todos os prêmios e indicações que receberam. E Scorsese dá um show de direção, com um roteiro redondo e preciso, uma montagem excepcional, que não permite que o filme torne-se cansativo com suas mais de 3 horas de duração, figurino excelente, direção de arte apuradíssima, uma aula de cinema. E o filme assume várias identidades. É um western a la corrida do ouro. É um filme de gangster, onde o silêncio a todos protege. É um filme policial, investigativo, com os integrantes do iniciante Bureau de Investigação tentando resolver o caso e prender os culpados. É uma denúncia de uma parte da história norte-americana que estava sendo apagada dos livros. E é uma fábula sobre ganância, preconceito, inveja, como somente o cinema e Scorsese podem produzir.
